author: By Niraj Chokshi, Glenn Thrush and Mark Walker
title: U.S. Is Said to Open Criminal Inquiry Into Boeing
description: The investigation is tied to an incident on an Alaska Airlines flight in early January. Boeing also told a Senate panel that it cannot find a record of the work done on the Alaska plane.
content: The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation into Boeing after a panel on one of the company’s planes blew out on an Alaska Airlines flight in early January, a person familiar with the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: Something Old. Something New. Something Thrifted.
description: Focused on recycled clothing, some brides are finding their wedding attire on vintage sites and at resale stores.
content: Last fall, Emmali Osterhoudt was at a Goodwill store in Birmingham, Ala., when she stumbled upon a Galia Lahav wedding gown. Though she was not yet engaged, Ms. Osterhoudt, 21, couldn’t pass up the opportunity to purchase the find: The gown was priced at $25.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal Shbair, Vivian Yee and Aaron Boxerman
title: The 10-Year-Old Boy Who Has Become the Face of Starvation in Gaza
description: The harrowing image of a skeletal Yazan Kafarneh circulated widely on social media and has served as a graphic warning about the enclave’s dire food situation.
content: It is all too easy to trace the skull beneath the Gazan boy’s face, the pallid skin stretching tight over every curve of bone and sagging with every hollow. His chin juts with a disturbing sharpness. His flesh has shrunk and shriveled, life reduced to little more than a thin mask over an imminent death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: A Former Trump Aide Becomes a Liberal Favorite
description: After breaking with her onetime boss, Alyssa Farah Griffin finds a warm welcome on “The View” and CNN.
content: Now and then during an election cycle, a Republican pundit becomes something of a hero to Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Says Ukraine Should Have the ‘Courage of the White Flag’
description: His words have raised questions about whether Francis was suggesting that Ukraine surrender, but a Vatican spokesman said the pope meant “cease-fire and negotiation.”
content: Pope Francis has reiterated in a new interview that Ukraine should negotiate to end the war with Russia, but this time he used language — adopting his interviewer’s expression, “white flag” — that has drawn attention and raised questions about whether the pope was suggesting that Ukraine surrender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Microplastics Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warns
description: At SXSW, a documentary traces the arc of plastics in our lives, and highlights evolving research of the potential harm of its presence in our bodies.
content: It’s been more than five decades since Dustin Hoffman’s character in “The Graduate” was offered a kernel of wisdom about the path to prosperity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: The Surprising Left-Right Alliance That Wants More Apartments in Suburbs
description: The YIMBY movement isn’t just for liberals any more. Legislators from both sides of the political divide are working to add duplexes and apartments to single-family neighborhoods.
content: For years, the Yimbytown conference was an ideologically safe space where liberal young professionals could talk to other liberal young professionals about the particular problems of cities with a lot of liberal young professionals: not enough bike lanes and transit, too many restrictive zoning laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: The Journalist Who Tried to Fight the Nazis With Radio Stories
description: In “How to Win an Information War,” Peter Pomerantsev looks to a World War II propagandist for lessons in the battle between Russia and Ukraine.
content: In 1931, the British journalist Sefton Delmer interviewed Adolf Hitler, whose long-shot presidential campaign he was covering for a British paper. “I realized in a flash the secret to his power,” Delmer wrote in The Daily Express. Hitler had “mesmerized millions of men and women into fanatical allegiance” with his impassioned gaze and “personal zealotry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Carol Rosenberg
title: Army Investigators Search for Answers After Helicopter Crash That Killed 3
description: Two National Guard soldiers and a Border Patrol agent died in the crash in Texas during what the military says was a routine mission on the border.
content: Army investigators on Saturday headed to the site where a military helicopter crashed in southern Texas the previous day, killing two National Guard soldiers and a Border Patrol agent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: William Whitworth, Revered Writer and Editor, Is Dead at 87
description: After writing memorable character sketches and fine-tuning others’ copy at The New Yorker, he spent two decades as editor in chief of The Atlantic Monthly.
content: William Whitworth, who wrote revealing profiles in The New Yorker giving voice to his idiomatic subjects and polished the prose of some of the nation’s celebrated writers as its associate editor before transplanting that magazine’s painstaking standards to The Atlantic, where he was editor in chief for 20 years, died on Friday in Conway, Ark., near Little Rock. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Pet Shop That Sold Sick and Hurt Puppies Will Repay Nearly 200 Customers
description: Shake A Paw agreed to settle a lawsuit brought by New York’s attorney general after investigators found that the Long Island business was selling puppies from so-called puppy mills.
content: The owners of a Long Island pet store accused of knowingly selling hundreds of sick and injured puppies, including some that died days after being bought, will pay $300,000 to about 200 customers under a settlement announced by New York’s attorney general on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Myung-Ok Lee
title: Dog Day Afternoon
description: My autistic son, the unleashed dogs of Manhattan and me.
content: My young adult son Jason and I are crossing Riverside Drive to get to the park on the other side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Cramming for the Oscars
description: It’s been a rough year for Hollywood, but the post-awards season landscape offers some hints of hope for audiences.
content: I’m in competition with no one but myself in trying to view all the major-category nominees for the Oscars before the ceremony tomorrow night. I’m doing well this year, probably because the slate is fairly small: Most of the films with acting and screenplay nominations are also contenders for best picture. If I can get over my aversion to biopics that I wish were documentaries instead, I have a good chance of going into the ceremony with the confidence of a dorky student who’s done all the reading for the final exam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Outfits of Epic Proportions
description: Otherworldly silhouettes and extravagant textures characterized the clothes seen on and off the runways at Paris Fashion Week.
content: Intricate textures, big chunky shoes and futuristic silhouettes were prevalent in the crowds at Paris Fashion Week, where Japanese labels like Comme des Garçons, Junya Watanabe and Yohji Yamamoto — all of which have long been favorites of the industry establishment — appeared to have infiltrated the wardrobes of many fans whose only view of the shows was from the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hallie Lieberman
title: Lily Gladstone for Best Actress? Oscars Gamblers Are Betting Big.
description: Inside the world of people making bets on the winners of the Academy Awards — with some taking home thousands of dollars.
content: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Victoria Kim
title: As U.S. Rushes to Build Gaza Port, Major Challenges Loom
description: Famine is stalking Gaza, but the American-led initiative faces daunting obstacles in logistics, security and cost.
content: As the United States military rushes to assemble a temporary port on the Gaza coast, daunting practical challenges to the seaborne humanitarian effort to stave off famine in the territory are becoming increasingly apparent. The obstacles include logistics, cost and security issues, diplomats and aid officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: New Biden Ad Pokes Fun at His Age: ‘I’m Not a Young Guy. That’s No Secret.’
description: The ad, which will target a youthful demographic, represents a shift in tone, trying to turn one of the president’s greatest perceived liabilities into an asset.
content: In a new advertisement for his re-election campaign, President Biden tries to take one of his greatest perceived liabilities as a candidate, his age, and turn it into an advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia’s Advance Around Avdiivka Loses Momentum After Quick Gains
description: Ukraine has committed significant forces to defending the area, and Russian troops are now attacking across open fields with little cover.
content: When the eastern city of Avdiivka, a Ukrainian stronghold, fell to Russian forces three weeks ago, Kyiv and its allies feared that Moscow’s troops could build on their momentum and quickly press ahead toward strategic military hubs and population centers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Northeast Braces for Heavy Rain After Severe Weather Moves Across the South
description: Forecasters said the New York City area could get up to two inches of rain into Sunday morning, with the highest totals expected in northeastern New Jersey.
content: A storm system that battered parts of the South with heavy rain on Saturday was expected to reach the Northeast, bringing with it the potential for coastal flooding and powerful winds, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Reese
title: A Food Writer Whose Essays Go Heavy on the Salt and Fire
description: Geraldine DeRuiter’s “If You Can’t Take the Heat” expands on her viral, award-winning blog posts.
content: Geraldine DeRuiter, the pungent voice behind the Everywhereist blog, knows how to rant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles, David C. Adams and Andre Paultre
title: With Haiti in Chaos, a Humanitarian Crisis Is Rapidly Unfolding
description: As gangs have united in concerted attacks against the state, the prime minister is stranded in Puerto Rico, and food, water, fuel and medical care are in short supply.
content: Dr. Ronald V. LaRoche has not been able to cross into dangerous territory to inspect the hospital he runs in Haiti’s Delmas 18 neighborhood since it was ransacked by gangs last week, but a TikTok video he saw offered clues to its current condition: It was on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: They Want to Make Palm Oil in a Lab. Without Palm Trees.
description: Palm oil. It’s in your snacks, your soap, pretty much everything. But palm oil plantations have caused vast deforestation. Can these three tech executives help fix things?
content: A handful of startups are trying to reinvent one of the most ubiquitous, but also environmentally destructive, ingredients in our diets: palm oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova and Manuela Andreoni
title: Rains Are Scarce in the Amazon. Instead, Megafires Are Raging.
description: Hundreds of square miles of the rainforest have burned as countries in the region battle a record number of fires fueled by extreme weather.
content: By this time of the year, rain should be drenching large swaths of the Amazon rainforest. Instead, a punishing drought has kept the rains at bay, creating dry conditions for fires that have engulfed hundreds of square miles of the rainforest that do not usually burn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson Drank There. Now You Can, Too.
description: A bar set built for “The Banshees of Inisherin” was discarded in a backyard after filming, then resurrected by a pub in Ireland. It’s up for sale.
content: It’s a quiet Thursday evening in Ireland’s rural midlands, and Mee’s Bar in Kilkerrin, County Galway, is hardly buzzing. The large space is mostly dark, the stools are mostly empty, and out front, on the only road through town, most cars roll by without stopping — foreboding features that have marked many an Irish country pub for dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Potential Obstacle to Trump Media’s Merger Appears to Have Been Cleared
description: Two early founders of Donald Trump’s social media company reached a temporary truce with the company on Saturday.
content: The threat of a last-minute obstacle to the merger of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company and a cash-rich shell company appears to have subsided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: About 600 Workers Unionize at Microsoft-Owned Activision
description: The group will become the largest union at a video game company in the United States, while Microsoft pledged to stay neutral on the vote.
content: About 600 workers at Activision Publishing, the video game maker owned by Microsoft, are unionizing, forming the largest video game workers’ union in the United States, the Communications Workers of America said on Friday. Microsoft recognized the union after the vote count was finalized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Shane Goldmacher
title: The Biden-Trump Rerun: A Nation Craving Change Gets More of the Same
description: Americans love a candidate who promises something new. But when a sitting president runs against a former one, can either claim the mantle of change?
content: The promise of change has been a powerful force in presidential campaigns for decades, a reliable appeal to a fundamental yearning in the American electorate. It was central to the candidacies of John F. Kennedy, Ronald Reagan, Barack Obama and Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Call to End Gambling Ads as Athletes and Celebrities Are Shut Out of Them
description: A group wants the federal government to mirror its blanket restrictions on tobacco ads, citing addiction and its effect on sports.
content: With the hockey season winding down, many Canadians have two things on their minds: their teams’ playoff chances and a barrage of television ads for online sports gambling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Petra Mathers, Author Whose Children’s Stories Soared, Dies at 78
description: Her winsome animal characters and their comic adventures expressed universal truths and feelings, rendered in a naïve and often surrealistic style.
content: Petra Mathers, a German-born children’s book illustrator and author whose kindly, often bumbling animal characters were nonetheless quietly heroic and often risked much for love, died on Feb. 6 at her home in Astoria, Ore. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Charge Man With Firing Shots Outside the Capitol on Jan. 6
description: The charges once again laid bare one of the most persistent myths about the attack promoted by pro-Trump politicians and media figures: that none of the rioters were armed.
content: A Trump supporter who prosecutors say fired a pistol into the air on the grounds of the Capitol as a mob stormed the building on Jan. 6, 2021, was charged on Friday with firearm offenses, trespassing and interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: This Prophetic Academic Now Foresees the West’s Defeat
description: Emmanuel Todd, a historian and anthropologist, has a knack for prediction.
content: “If anybody in this room thinks Putin will stop at Ukraine, I assure you, he will not,” President Biden said during his State of the Union address on Thursday night. Europe is “at risk,” he added, as he welcomed Ulf Kristersson, the prime minister of Sweden, the newest member of NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Sapna Maheshwari
title: Biden the President Wants to Curb TikTok. Biden the Candidate Embraces Its Stars.
description: At a party for social media influencers at the White House this week, President Biden’s political concerns collided with his national security concerns.
content: The White House is so concerned about the security risks of TikTok that federal workers are not allowed to use the app on their government phones. Top Biden administration officials have even helped craft legislation that could ban TikTok in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: How Fraudsters Break Into Social Security Accounts and Steal Benefits
description: Thousands of people receiving Social Security benefits have had their money diverted into criminal accounts. Here’s what to know.
content: For the past two decades, Liz Birenbaum’s 88-year-old mother, Marge, has received her Social Security check on the second Wednesday of each month. It’s her sole source of income, which pays for her room at a long-term care center, where she landed last October after having a stroke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Police Shoot and Kill Man Suspected of Stabbing a Woman at a Party
description: The police said they had found the man, 46, holding a knife in the hallway of a Queens apartment building when they responded to reports of an assault.
content: A 46-year-old man died Friday night after police officers in Queens shot at him four times and used a Taser because they said he was wielding a knife after a dispute at a social gathering, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Toyota’s Hybrid-First Strategy Is Delivering Big Profits
description: Toyota, the world’s largest automaker, has been criticized for selling few electric vehicles, but its decision to focus on hybrids is paying off financially.
content: In today’s high-tech, high-stakes auto industry, fortunes can change quickly, and there’s no better example of that right now than Toyota Motor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Four Years on, the Mysteries of Covid Are Unraveling
description: Are superdodgers real? Is Covid seasonal? And what’s behind its strangest symptoms? Here’s what we’ve learned.
content: When the World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a global pandemic in March 2020, nearly everything about the novel coronavirus was an open question: How was it spreading so quickly? How sick would it make people? Would a single bout buy you protection from future cases?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mateo Askaripour
title: He Played the Victim. It Earned Him Attention, Success and a Lot of Trouble.
description: In Andrew Boryga’s debut novel, a young writer creates a career for himself by exaggerating, or sometimes completely manufacturing, stories of tragedy.
content: There’s real value in being a victim. Serious profit in pity, but only so long as you don’t become too ambitious, too greedy or too arrogant. Veer too far, and you run the risk of becoming dependent on disaster. That’s when real trouble ensues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘Free to Be … You and Me’ Took the Revolution to the Playground
description: Fifty years ago, the TV landmark showed Gen X kids that no one else has the right to tell you who you are.
content: “Free to Be … You and Me,” the 1974 kids-TV special and feminist milestone, begins with footage of children riding a carousel. I was one of them. Not literally — I watched the show on TV like millions of other baby Gen X-ers. But these kids, laughing and spinning, were my cohort at a strange point in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Sweden and Canada to Restart Payments to U.N. Agency for Palestinians
description: The countries were among those that suspended payments to the  agency, known as UNRWA, after Israel accused a dozen of its employees of taking part in Hamas-led terrorist attacks on Oct. 7.
content: Canada and Sweden are resuming funding for the main United Nations agency supporting Palestinian refugees in Gaza, citing the spiraling humanitarian catastrophe there and saying that the agency had taken steps to improve accountability amid accusations that some of its employees had links to Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: MacGyvering
description: Let’s see if we can puzzle our way out of John Guzzetta’s tough themeless.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid is all about its innovative verbiage, which could be contorted into a portmanteau; let’s not try to make “innoverbiage” happen, though. John Guzzetta has made New York Times crosswords for every day of the week, but he’s a particular whiz at a themeless: This is his 20th construction that has run on a Friday or Saturday. I love the way offbeat elements are peppered throughout this puzzle; big oddball surprises alternate with little deadpan touches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Signs Legislation to Extend Funding for Critical Departments
description: With a partial shutdown averted, President Biden and Congress face tough negotiations ahead to finance the remaining federal agencies and departments by March 22.
content: President Biden signed a $460 billion spending package on Saturday to avert a shutdown of critical federal departments even as lawmakers continue to wrestle over a financing blueprint for many other agencies more than halfway into the current fiscal year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Clears $460 Billion Bill to Avert Partial Shutdown, Sending It to Biden
description: The White House said the executive branch was halting shutdown preparations and that President Biden would sign the bill on Saturday. But the spending fight isn’t over yet.
content: The Senate gave final approval on Friday to a $460 billion spending bill to fund about half the federal government through the fall, sending the legislation to President Biden’s desk with just hours to spare to avert a partial shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Ireland Rejects Constitution Changes, Keeping ‘Women in the Home’ Language
description: Two proposed amendments, which voters considered on Friday, were intended to reflect the more secular, liberal values of the nation’s modern era.
content: Voters in Ireland rejected two proposed changes to the country’s Constitution that would have removed language about women’s duties being in the home and broadened the definition of family beyond marriage, dealing a blow to the government that analysts said suggested the weakness of their campaign to pass the proposals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euny Hong
title: How ‘Past Lives’ Changed My Mind About My Relationship
description: In the movie’s central love triangle, I rooted for one outcome. But my dating life told a different story.
content: My most stressful moviegoing experience last year was not the mushroom cloud in “Oppenheimer” or the murder trial scenes in “Anatomy of a Fall,” but watching the story of a love triangle among a Korean American woman, a Korean guy and a white guy in the Oscar-nominated “Past Lives.” In the film, Nora, our 30-something heroine, and Arthur, her white husband, are living happily in New York when Nora is contacted by Hae Sung, her childhood sweetheart in South Korea, with whom she had reconnected online as a young adult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: ‘You Can Hear a Pin Drop’: The Rise of Super Strict Schools in England
description: Inspired by the academic success of schools like the Michaela secondary school in northwest London, some principals are introducing tight controls on students’ behavior.
content: As the teacher started to count down, the students uncrossed their arms and bowed their heads, completing the exercise in a flash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker
title: How Trump’s Justice Dept. Derailed an Investigation of a Major Company
description: The industrial giant Caterpillar hired William Barr and other lawyers to defuse a federal criminal investigation of alleged tax dodges.
content: In December 2018, a team of federal law enforcement agents flew to Amsterdam to interview a witness in a yearslong criminal investigation into Caterpillar, which had avoided billions of dollars of income taxes by shifting profits to a Swiss subsidiary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Navalny’s Heirs Seek a Political Future in Russia
description: Aleksei Navalny’s team has found a new leader in the opposition leader’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya. But Navalny’s death has so far brought little change to their insular tactics.
content: Aleksei A. Navalny built Russia’s largest opposition force in his image, embodying a freer, fairer Russia for millions. His exiled team now faces the daunting task of steering his political movement without him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 13 Things We’re Still Mad About: Oscars Edition
description: We asked staffers in Culture and Books about the snubs from years past that still bother them, and they had some things to say.
content: I have never forgiven the Oscars for picking “Birdman” over “Boyhood.” What can I say — “Boyhood” was moving and meaningful, while “Birdman” was pretentious and obtuse, and none of my cinéaste colleagues are going to persuade me otherwise. MICHAEL PAULSON, theater reporter
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Frostbitten Kansas City Fans Needed Amputations After Frigid Game
description: A Missouri hospital said the amputations involved mostly fingers and toes after a game in January when temperatures were below zero.
content: Several fans of the Kansas City Chiefs who attended a playoff game on a bitterly cold January day in Missouri suffered frostbite that required amputations, according to the hospital that treated them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: The Meaning of Influence, Written in the Stars
description: Celestial bodies have influence. So do drinks, advertisers and a TikTok personality known as Pookie.
content: Madison Malone Kircher, who reports on internet culture for The New York Times, has written about several influencers this year. One competed in the Mrs. World pageant two weeks after giving birth. Another, known as Pookie, drew the fascination — and ire — of TikTok users. A third “rose to viral fame for her leftover salmon recipe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: These Oscar Snubs Still Rile Up Readers
description: You can’t forgive the Academy for passing up “Brokeback Mountain” or omitting Amy Adams in “Arrival,” among other oversights that still sting.
content: Some things will always stick in your craw. When I asked readers, ahead of the Academy Awards on Sunday, if they were still mad about an Oscar snub, boy, did I get an earful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Miami Beach Is Done With Spring Breakers: ‘It’s Not Us. It’s You.’
description: This weekend and next, Miami Beach visitors will face extraordinary measures meant to head off disorderly crowds, including bag checks at beach entrances and closed parking garages.
content: More than two decades ago, Wayne Jones traveled to Daytona Beach, then Florida’s spring break mecca, not to party but to study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Panorama of Design
description: A look at design-world events, products and people.
content: Love’s bonds can be delicate yet feel constraining and require hard work to maintain. How better to express all that than by slicing paper into handmade greeting cards, with whorls that can be pulled up to form gossamer cages for images of lovebirds, bouquets, engagement rings, or even rodents?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W.J. Hennigan and Phoebe Lett
title: ‘Oppenheimer’ Is the Origin Story. These Three Movies Reveal Our Nuclear Present.
description: This Oscars weekend: How films and culture help us imagine the unimaginable.
content: The national security writer W. J. Hennigan has spent many years ringing the alarm about the world’s new nuclear era — the subject of At The Brink, a new series from New York Times Opinion — and the crisis on the horizon. For anyone whose interest was piqued by the origin story of nuclear weapons in “Oppenheimer,” Mr. Hennigan, who happens to be a movie buff, recommends three essential films that illuminate our new nuclear era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex de Waal
title: I Said the Era of Famines Might Be Ending. I Was Wrong.
description: Many things go into the conditions that create a food crisis: crop failures, high food prices, unemployment. But it’s war that has created the famines unfolding today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Speaks Out About ‘Hateful’ Online Bullying
description: In an appearance at SXSW, Meghan said she experienced the heaviest online abuse during her pregnancies.
content: The glare of public attention has often left Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, on the receiving end of strong opinions. And Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, pushed back at that directly on Friday, criticizing a culture of bullying on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: BMW Is a Surprise Winner in Electric Vehicles
description: Once considered a laggard, the German luxury carmaker is one of only a few established automakers that has been able to compete effectively against Tesla.
content: As BMW car bodies glided down an assembly line in Munich recently, showered by sparks from robotic welders, it was hard to tell which vehicles would be powered by batteries, fuel-burning engines or both. In the view of many analysts, that is not a good thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: National Guard in the Subway? A Transit Reporter Explains.
description: Ana Ley covers mass transit and commuters in New York City. In an interview, she discussed Gov. Kathy Hochul’s decision to beef up security on the city’s subway.
content: The New York City subway is full of surprises, and Ana Ley, who covers mass transit for The Times, is used to waking up not knowing where her reporting will take her next. Still, Ms. Ley was shocked on Wednesday when Gov. Kathy Hochul announced she was deploying members of the National Guard to patrol subway stations and assist the police officers who inspect riders’ bags.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Two Novels About Social Withdrawal
description: A chilly marriage; a catatonic protagonist.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric V. Copage
title: They Married, Divorced and Then Married Their Ex-Spouses Again
description: Five couples share how and why they decided to reconcile and tie the knot again.
content: Famous couples who marry, divorce and then remarry their former spouses are often fodder for tabloid headlines. Think of the actors Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, who were married to each other twice — first for a decade beginning in 1964, and then again in 1975 before they divorced the next year. Elon Musk and Talulah Riley were wed from 2010 to 2012 and again from 2013 to 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Baffled Londoners Start Spreading the Schmear
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 9, 2024.
content: “I can’t tell you how many times I say, ‘sesame, black sesame, poppy, garlic, onion and salt’ — it literally just comes off the tip of my tongue now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fiona Maazel
title: This Debut Novel Is a Wondrous Babel of Ideas and Language
description: In “The Extinction of Irena Rey,” a writer goes missing and her translators give pursuit — until things get weird.
content: In gist: Oh my mushrooms, “The Extinction of Irena Rey” is incredibly strange, savvy, sly and hard to classify. I also couldn’t put it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Lisa Ann Walter of ‘Abbott Elementary’ on the Show She’ll Never Forget
description: “I would challenge anybody to see Patti LuPone in her prime sing ‘Evita,’” the actress said, “and not say, ‘That was the best show I’ve ever seen in my life.’”
content: It was a Monday morning in Los Angeles and Lisa Ann Walter had the day off from “Abbott Elementary,” the ABC sitcom about an underfunded public school in Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Isabella Burton
title: The Long, Strange History of ‘Manifesting’
description: Americans have long been attracted to the idea that we can shape reality with our will.
content: Reality is what you make it — at least according to those who believe in manifesting, the art and quasi-spiritual science of willing things into existence through the power of desire, attention and focus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve M. Kahn
title: Maps Are for More Than Just Finding Your Way
description: In the digital age, old-fashioned maps were expected to die out. But just look around the room.
content: “Looking at a map is like looking into a fire in a fireplace; there’s a sense of something happening all the time, and it draws you in,” said Anders Mattsson, a cabinetmaker for Svenskt Tenn.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fighting Hopelessness in Treating Addiction
description: Readers praise a column by Nicholas Kristof about an effective program.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Michael Crowley
title: Providing Both Bombs and Food, Biden Puts Himself in the Middle of Gaza’s War
description: The president’s decision to send aid by air and sea represents a shift prompted by the growing humanitarian crisis. But it raised uncomfortable questions about America’s role.
content: From the skies over Gaza these days fall American bombs and American food pallets, delivering death and life at the same time and illustrating President Biden’s elusive effort to find balance in an unbalanced Middle East war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger
title: Britt Tells Misleading Border Story in State of the Union Response
description: The Alabama senator used a story about sex trafficking to criticize the Biden administration’s border policies. But the events occurred in Mexico years ago.
content: The opposition party’s response to the State of the Union address is a golden opportunity for up-and-coming and lesser-known politicians to introduce themselves to the nation and boost their political profile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden Makes a Rare Mention of Marijuana in the State of the Union
description: The president pointed toward his efforts to ease restrictions on cannabis, a potential signal that he could talk more during the campaign about an issue he has been reluctant to embrace.
content: Buried in President Biden’s fiery re-election pitch in his State of the Union address on Thursday night was a brief mention of an issue he has often been reluctant to embrace: marijuana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Luscious Miso Leeks With White Beans
description: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s satisfying take on leeks vinaigrette combines silky leeks with a mustardy miso dressing and creamy white beans.
content: I respect leeks. They stand firm and tall above their allium kin, their jade-green tops proudly poking out from your grocery bag. They make you work for them, with all that careful washing to rinse the sand and grit from between their layers. (They’re also, as far as I know, the only vegetable to be constantly carried by a Pokémon.) And leeks are thoughtful — they don’t make you cry as you chop them for your meal. (I’m looking at you, onions.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Heretics
description: The Rev. Carlton Pearson was a rising evangelical star — until he rejected hell.
content: The story of the Rev. Carlton Pearson, who was a rising star in the evangelical movement until he cast aside the idea of hell and, with it, everything he’d worked for over his entire life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: These May Be the Oldest Olive Trees in the World
description: While the sentinel trees of Northern Lebanon may not be as old as some traditions hold, one tree might be more than 1,000 years old.
content: Olive trees are common in Northern Lebanon, but in the village of Bshaaleh, a handful look downright ancient. Their branches grow in wildly unpredictable directions, and the trees’ gray, gnarled trunks are shot through with holes and crevasses large enough to hide a sleeping child. Many people believe these sentinel trees are thousands of years old. They are known as “Noah trees” because of some people’s belief that the trees are the source of the olive branch carried by the dove back to Noah’s ark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Nocera and Ephrat Livni
title: What Would Paying Student Athletes Look Like?
description: A college team’s vote to unionize adds pressure on the N.C.A.A. to abandon rules that forbid paying student athletes like employees.
content: “Unions are tricky for college sports,” Jay Bilas, the ESPN college basketball analyst, said over the phone the other day, “because you’ve got public and private institutions and different state laws.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

author: By Nancy A. Ruhling
title: How a Pioneering Jazz Musician and Teacher Spends Her Sundays
description: There weren’t many female jazz musicians when Carol Sudhalter started her career. Now she spends her Sundays sharing what she has learned.
content: Although Carol Sudhalter’s first love was the flute, she was also seduced by the saxophone early in her career as a jazz musician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: ‘People Are Hoping That Israel Nukes Us So We Get Rid of This Pain’
description: A father’s desperate texts from Gaza offer a window into five months of suffering there.
content: When President Biden weighs American policy toward Gaza, may he think of a gentle scholar named Mohammed Alshannat.

title: Corrections: March 9, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 9, 2024.
content: An article on Tuesday out racial profiling by police in Japan misstated the publication year for the training manual used by police in the Aichi prefecture. It was published in 2009, not 2021.

author: By Steven Erlanger, Roger Cohen and Erika Solomon
title: Macron and Scholz, Never Close, Spar Over Policy Toward Ukraine and Russia
description: A fraught relationship has recently turned bitter, with insults and barbs threatening European unity at a critical moment.
content: It was a private dinner in a Parisian garden on the Boulevard St. Germain, meant to cement the important personal relationship between the leaders of France and Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why It’s Hard to Explain Joe Biden’s Unpopularity
description: A theory of why Biden’s presidency has so far been a political flop.
content: Joe Biden is one of the most unpopular presidents in modern American history. In Gallup polling, his approval ratings are lower than those of any president embarking on a re-election campaign, from Dwight Eisenhower to Donald Trump.

title: Can You Create a Diverse College Class Without Affirmative Action?
description: The Supreme Court effectively ended race-based admissions preferences. But will selective schools still be able to achieve diverse student bodies? Here’s how they might try.
content: The Supreme Court effectively ended race-based admissions preferences. But will selective schools still be able to achieve diverse student bodies? Here’s how they might try.

description: A U.S. district judge allowed the Biden administration to continue a program that it has used to give temporary legal status to hundreds of thousands of citizens of Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua and Venezuela.
content: A U.S. district judge allowed the Biden administration to continue a program that it has used to give temporary legal status to hundreds of thousands of citizens of Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua and Venezuela.

title: Three Is Best: How China’s Family Planning Propaganda Has Changed
description: Faced with a shrinking and aging population, China is using propaganda channels to send the message: have more babies.
